Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mio-Pliocene evolution of the Indian summer monsoon recorded in the Bengal Fan
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Indian monsoon brings moisture to the Indian subcontinent and the Himalayas, feeding some of Earth's largest river systems, including the Ganges-Brahmaputra. This is one of the largest and the most populated river basins in the world, providing water for ~1 billion people. The rivers sweep sediments from around the basin into the Indian Ocean, where they accumulate in a "megafan", a giant deposit beyond the river mouth that extends as far south as the southern tip of India. These sediments preserve traces of millions of years of environmental changes in the region, including valuable molecular fingerprints of forests and grasslands and Indian monsoonal summer rainfall amounts.

This research engages the collaborative efforts of faculty, graduate students and undergraduate students at the University of Southern California and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, along with national and international collaborations, to address societally-relevant climate, and more broadly earth science, research. Specifically, this research uses sediment cores from the center and the southern end of the Bengal megafan to study the nature and causes of the vegetation and monsoon precipitation changes on land and carbon burial in the Bengal megafan over the last 18 million years. The research team will also use organic carbon contents of the sediments to calculate the amount of carbon buried by the megafan, locked away from the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. The central hypothesis that will be tested is that the intensity of precipitation in the summer monsoon has varied since initiation and has driven changes in the Himalayan carbon cycle. Precipitation changes are expected to be associated with: 1) global warmth in the mid-Miocene and early Pliocene (when pCO2 levels were similar to today); 2) wind speed intensification in the Mio-Pliocene; and 3) cooling in the Pleistocene. Analytical methods include compound-specific hydrogen isotopic analyses of plant leaf waxes, which when paired with carbon isotopes can resolve whether hydrological changes drove C4 plant expansion in the region. Pairing further with inorganic proxies will establish how erosive changes impacted organic carbon burial in the Bengal Fan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Indian Monsoon represents a major feature of the Earth’s climate system with a profound impact today on the hydrology, ecology and carbon cycle of a vast region of the planet. Documenting and understanding the nature and timing of hydrological changes in the Indian Monsoon in Earth history is essential to understanding the major ecological and carbon cycle changes that have occurred in the past, and also to inform on the transformations that we might expect in the future. This study sought to study the sensitivity of the Indian Monsoon, including the wettest places on Earth, to changes in global climate across the last 26 Myrs. Specifically, this study aimed at resolving large uncertainties about the timing, nature and causes of Indian Monsoon precipitation changes across the Miocene and Pliocene, a period in which the Himalayan range and Tibetan plateau had already achieved a very high and stable elevation.

We approached this problem with the study of organic molecules specifically produced on land by vascular plants – so called biomarkers - and delivered to and buried in marine sediments of the Bengal fan, as well as bulk geochemistry and relevant sedimentological properties. We sampled multiple cores along a transect across the distal Bengal Fan recently drilled during IODP expedition 354. During the expedition, we made discoveries about the nature of sedimentation and the presence of terrestrial organic matter, including massive accumulations of wood fragments thousands of kilometers from land. These new high quality sediment cores and our geochemical analyses have yielded biomarkers, that offer paleoclimate and vegetation reconstruction across the last 26 Ma and also to constrain carbon burial in the Bengal Fan – the largest repository of sediment and organic carbon on earth.

Specifically, our study significantly revised the age of the expansion of C4 plants (i.e. savanna-like ecosystems) in the Himalayan foreland basin (from 7-8 Ma to 6 Ma). In addition, our study provides evidence for an earlier C4 plant expansion (earlier than 15 Ma) in Peninsular India than in the Himalayan system. Further, for the first time, our study provided direct evidences that a weakening of the Indian summer monsoon during the late Miocene led to the C4 expansion. Lastly, we found direct evidences of a strong summer monsoon during the late Oligocene and early Miocene. Overall, our study thus profoundly changed our understanding of the long term evolution of the Indian summer monsoon and associated ecological and carbon cycle implications. To that end, we discovered a climate-induced doubling in organic carbon burial efficiency at the Plio-Pleistocene transition, revealing a new climate forcing of the carbon cycle.

In addition, this project has supported an early career female faculty member (Feakins) as well as several graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Southern California (USC). It has provided new training and professional development opportunities for these participants, through their collaborative involvement, including extended visits to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI). This project has also continued to foster the development of collaborations between the Feakins group at USC, the Galy lab at WHOI and international colleagues in France (CRPG-CNRS and University of Grenoble) and Germany (University of Bremen).
